title: AB 1850
content: The people of California enact the following. Section 13000 of the Education Code is amended to establish the California Civil Liberties Public Education Act, aiming to educate the public about the historical events of Japanese American exclusion, forced removal, and internment. The federal Commission on Wartime Relocation and Internment of Civilians (CWRIC) was created by Congress in 1980 to review Executive Order 9066's impact on American citizens and recommend remedies. The CWRIC issued reports in 1983 based on hearings with over 750 witnesses, including evacuees and government officials. The federal Commission on Wartime Relocation and Internment of Civilians (CWRIC) conducted hearings with over 750 witnesses, including evacuees, government officials, public figures, interested citizens, and historians. The CWRIC concluded that the internment of Japanese-Americans during World War II was not justified by military necessity, but rather driven by race prejudice, war hysteria, and a failure of political leadership. This policy was a result of ignorance and executed in an atmosphere of fear and anger towards Japan, leading to a grave personal injustice. The internment of Japanese-Americans during World War II was driven by race prejudice, war hysteria, and a failure of political leadership. It was executed in an atmosphere of fear and anger at Japan, resulting in a grave personal injustice to American citizens and resident aliens of Japanese ancestry. President Ronald Reagan signed the federal Civil Liberties Act of 1988, declaring it a great day for America. The Congress acknowledges the grave injustice done to citizens and residents of Japanese ancestry during WWII, motivated by racial prejudice and wartime hysteria. This led to significant damages and losses in education and job training. The Congress apologizes on behalf of the Nation for the fundamental violations of civil liberties and constitutional rights of individuals of Japanese ancestry during WWII, resulting in significant human suffering and lack of appropriate compensation. The Education Code is amended to require eligible aliens seeking permanent residency in California under the federal Immigration Reform and Control Act of 1986 to demonstrate English proficiency and knowledge of U.S. history and government. The Legislature aims to establish a state test for eligible aliens to demonstrate English proficiency and knowledge of U.S. history and government, in line with federal immigration laws. Section 32400 of the Education Code is amended to require eligible undocumented foreign nationals to demonstrate English proficiency and knowledge of U.S. history and government under the federal Immigration Reform and Control Act of 1986. The Legislature intends to establish a state test for eligible foreign nationals to demonstrate English proficiency and knowledge of U.S. history and government to meet federal requirements. The Superintendent, in consultation with the Chancellor of the California Community Colleges, will develop a test to measure English proficiency and knowledge of U.S. history and government for eligible foreign nationals, in compliance with federal requirements. The Governor, Superintendent, Chancellor of the California Community Colleges, President pro Tempore of the Senate, and Speaker of the Assembly will seek approval from the US Immigration and Naturalization Service and Attorney General to use a test for eligible foreign nationals to meet requirements under the Immigration Reform and Control Act of 1986. The Superintendent will distribute a test to educational agencies for eligible foreign nationals granted legal status under the Immigration Reform and Control Act of 1986. This test will help determine the need for appropriate educational services for these individuals. The Superintendent will distribute a test to educational agencies for eligible foreign nationals granted legal status under the Immigration Reform and Control Act of 1986 to assess the need for educational services. Test results are confidential and can only be released with written consent for educational purposes. Upon request, results may be shared with the United States Immigration and Naturalization Service. School districts, county offices of education, community colleges, and other eligible agencies must administer the test with appropriate security measures for federal funds received for this purpose. Section 52613 of the Education Code is amended to include appropriate security measures for federal funds received for testing purposes. Each governing board of a school district offering classes for adult nonimmigrant foreign nationals must charge a fee to cover the full costs of instruction, not exceeding the actual cost. The governing board of school districts offering adult classes for nonimmigrant foreign nationals must charge a fee to cover the full costs of instruction, not exceeding the actual cost. The fee must be adopted at least 90 days before the classes begin. No school district offering adult classes for nonimmigrant foreign nationals can include F-1 visa students in English and citizenship or elementary subjects classes for funding purposes. The Education Code defines terms like "Board of Governors" and "Chancellor" for this chapter. The Education Code defines terms like "Chancellor" as the Chancellor of the California Community Colleges and "Department" as the State Department of Education. Community-based organizations are approved by the Superintendent to provide educational services to eligible legalized persons. Educational outreach activities are also defined. The curr_chunk discusses the requirements of the federal Immigration and Nationality Act of 1986 for temporary resident foreign nationals, including adjustment of resident status, sources of assistance, rights and responsibilities, identification of services, and the importance of identifying oneself as a temporary resident to service providers. The curr_chunk emphasizes the importance of identifying oneself as a temporary resident foreign national to service providers, excluding client counseling or assuming responsibility for the adjustment of resident status. The curr_chunk discusses educational opportunities for immigrants, defining "immigrant" and "newly legalized person" as individuals eligible for education services in California. The curr_chunk defines key terms related to educational services for immigrants in California, including "Services provider," "SLIAG," and "Superintendent." Section 68062 of the Education Code is amended to provide rules for determining a person's residence, stating that there can only be one residence, it is where one stays when not elsewhere for work or special purposes, and can only be changed by both action and intent. It also specifies that a woman's residence is not dependent on her husband's. The residence of an unmarried minor is determined by the parent with whom they live, or the parent with whom they last lived if both parents are deceased. The minor's residence cannot be changed by their own actions, legal guardianship, or relinquishment of parental rights. A foreign national, including an unmarried minor, may establish residence in the United States, unless prohibited by federal immigration laws. The residence of an unmarried minor is determined by their parents. Section 68130.5 of the Education Code is amended to exempt certain students from paying nonresident tuition at California State University and California Community Colleges if they meet specific requirements, including high school attendance in California for three or more years. To qualify for exemption from nonresident tuition at California State University and California Community Colleges, students must have attended a California high school for three or more years, earned credits equivalent to three years of high school coursework in California, graduated from a California high school or equivalent, and be enrolled in an accredited institution of higher education in California since the fall of 2001. Students without lawful immigration status can be exempt from nonresident tuition by filing an affidavit with the institution of higher education, stating their intent to legalize their immigration status. The Board of Governors of the California Community Colleges and the Trustees of the California State University will establish rules for this exemption. Student information obtained in the implementation of this section is confidential. Income received as reparation payments for Japanese internment after October 1, 1990, will not affect financial need for applicants. Income received as reparation payments from the Canadian government for Japanese internment during World War II will not impact financial need for applicants. The Superintendent of Public Instruction must certify the enactment of the CHANGE Act by January 20, 2017, for Sections 3 to 8 of the act to become operative. The CHANGE Act replaces the term "alien" with "foreign national" in reference to non-citizens in an executive agency of the federal government. The term "illegal alien" is replaced with "undocumented foreign national" for individuals unlawfully present in the US. If the Superintendent certifies it, Section 2 of the act will become inoperative.
